item.title: How BBC visualize data?
item.description: if(!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") ## Loading required package: pacman p_load("tidyverse", "bbplot", "readxl", "viridis", "wesanderson") ## Installing package into 'C:/Users/Habac/Documents/R/win-library/3.5' ## (as 'lib' is unspecified) ## Warning: unable to access index for repository http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/pub/RWin/bin/windows/contrib/3.5: ## no fue posible abrir la URL 'http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/pub/RWin/bin/windows/contrib/3.5/PACKAGES' ## package 'wesanderson' successfully unpacked and MD5 sums checked ## ## The downloaded binary packages are in ## C:\Users\Habac\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpaG8SHD\downloaded_packages ## ## wesanderson installed imdb_tbl <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheEconomist/graphic-detail-data/master/data/2018-11-24_tv-ratings/IMDb_Economist_tv_ratings.csv") imdb_tbl_1 <- imdb_tbl %>% group_by(titleId) %>% mutate(number_season = n()) %>% filter(row_number(titleId) == 1) %>% select(titleId, title, number_season) %>% arrange(desc(number_season)) %>% ungroup() %>% group_by(number_season) %>% mutate(n = n()) %>% filter(row_number() == 1) %>% ungroup() %>% mutate(percent = n/sum(n), season = paste0("S", number_season)) %>% arrange(desc(percent)) %>% filter(n >= 15) g <- ggplot(imdb_tbl_1, aes(x = season, y = percent)) + geom_bar(colour = "black", stat = "identity", position = "identity", fill = "orange") + geom_hline(yintercept = 0, size = 1, colour="#333333") + bbc_style() + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) + theme(axis.

item.title: One of the New Feature of ggplot2 3.0
item.description: Why this post? Some time ago Dina Pomeranz posted on twitter a brief article about how the gender gaps has been falling in most countries, if you don’t believe me: The unadjusted gender wage gap for full time workers has been falling significantly in most countries: https://t.co/k7olIo40ZA pic.twitter.com/uknetWXajw — Dina D. Pomeranz (@DinaPomeranz) July 4, 2018 After reading the post1, I decided to replicate the entire article using the new features of ggplot2 3.
